title: Hideki Matsuyama Wins the Masters and Makes History for Japan
sub_head: The 29-year-old became the first Japanese man to win a major when he survived late drama and miscues to earn a green jacket
body:
AUGUSTA, Ga.—Hideki Matsuyama had the weight of a golf-obsessed, yet championship-deprived country hovering over every shot at Augusta National Golf Club on Sunday as he sought to become the first man from Japan to win one of golf’s major championships.
And just when it looked like he was about to run away with this Masters, he flirted with a meltdown, putting a shot in the water and watching his five-shot lead shrink to two on the back nine.
But with a collection of Japanese fans following him, Matsuyama recovered and became the first Japanese man to win a major championship. He won by one stroke with a 10-under par performance for the tournament that overcame a serious wobble down the stretch.  He could finally exhale and slip into a green jacket.
The victory completed the rise of a 29-year-old who burst onto the scene at this very course a decade ago and became one of the sport’s bright young talents and one of Asia’s all-time greats even before this win that quickly vacillated between near certitude and epic disaster.
“Hopefully, I’ll be a pioneer,” Matsuyama said afterward.
